purpleculture_pinyin:
liú
precious stone
драгоценный камень
rtega_mnemonic:
瑠瑠RS璢琉precious stone
  • stop work in the field 留/畱 to look at a precious stone 玉
  • uncultivated 㐬 person looking at a precious stone 玉
heisig_constituent: marine blue, king, jewel, ball, detain, receipt, dagger, sword, rice field, brains
koohiiStory1: “The king has been detained by some marines!” “How do you know they were marines?” “Because they were wearing marine blue.”.
koohiiStory2: The king was detained, by men in marine blue; Must be the marines, planning a coup. (thx Katsuo/gavmck).
WaniKani_Radicals: 王, ム, 刀, 田
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic:
The king will send his men with swords into your private rice paddy if you come across lapis lazuli. Even though this is your private land, he wants that lapis lazuli to make some new crowns and thrones for himself. Plus he's the king, so he can do whatever he wants.
If you've never taken an art history class (or played Minecraft) you may never have come across lapis lazuli, but think of it as a pretty, blue precious stone that people really, really liked in the olden days.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Watch the king's swords digging in your private rice paddy and digging up huge chunks of lapis lazuli. This isn't fair, that lapis should belong to you.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: You run up and ask how this lapis lazuli thievery isn't illegal and one of the swordsmen just shouts, "Loophole (る)!" What? What loophole? What law says that the king gets to steal your stuff?
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine reading through a giant text called "The Law" and looking for this loophole the king's men claim to have about taking your lapis lazuli. You can't find it... but maybe if you search just a bit longer...
Ru_AutoNotes:
Лазурит (ляпис-лазурь) — непрозрачный минерал от синего до голубовато-серого или зеленовато-серого цвета, лучшими считают камни сочно синие или сине-фиолетовые, а также насыщенно голубые.

Лазурит из Афганистана в естественном виде

Из него изготовляют декоративные вазы, шкатулки, статуэтки, применяют для инкрустации в художественных мозаичных работах, а также для облицовки колонн, каминов и др.

Фигурка из лазурита
Ru_Notes:
Используется в основном в составе слова 瑠璃るり, в ряде названий.
Сравни: 琉 (リュウ、ル драгоценный камень, лазурит), 瑠 (ル、リュウ лазурит, ляпис-лазурь, лазуревый камень), 璃 (リ лазурит, лазуревый камень; стекло).
Ru_Words:
瑠璃色るりいろ
  • ярко-синий цвет, ультрамарин
    • warodai
    瑠璃るり
  • мин. ляпис-лазурь, лазурит
  • уст. стекло
    • warodai
    瑠璃鳥るりちょう
  • восточная синяя птица, Myiophonus insularis Gould
    • warodai
    瑠璃県巣るりかけす
  • орнит. сойка Лидта, Lalocitta lidthi Bonaparte
    • warodai
Ru_Radicals: 刀 (катана), 厶 (значок МУ), 王 (монарх), 田 (рисовое поле)
Kanshudo_mnemonic: what detains (留) the king (王) is lapis lazuli

瑠字的基本解释

瑠
liú
古同“琉”。

瑠字的汉语字典释义

[①]［liú］
［《集韻》力求切，平尤，來。］
亦作“瑠1”。亦作“璢1”。
见“琉璃”。

瑠字的康熙字典解释

【午集上】【玉字部】　瑠； 康熙笔画：15； 页码：页738第19
【字彙】俗璢字。

瑠字的源字形

字形对比：

中国大陆宋体台湾细明体日本明朝体韩国明朝体旧字形
瑠字的起名意思

古同“琉”，有琉璃之义，也可形容人机灵、聪明。

Name meaning
In ancient times, "Liu" has the meaning of colored glaze, and it can also be described as clever and smart.
liú
вм. 琉
Radicals: 王, ム, 刀, 田  (king, private, sword, rice-paddy)
Meaning Mnemonic
The king will send his men with swords into your private rice paddy if you come across lapis lazuli. Even though this is your private land, he wants that lapis lazuli to make some new crowns and thrones for himself. Plus he's the king, so he can do whatever he wants.
If you've never taken an art history class (or played Minecraft) you may never have come across lapis lazuli, but think of it as a pretty, blue precious stone that people really, really liked in the olden days.
Watch the king's swords digging in your private rice paddy and digging up huge chunks of lapis lazuli. This isn't fair, that lapis should belong to you.
Reading Mnemonic
You run up and ask how this lapis lazuli thievery isn't illegal and one of the swordsmen just shouts, "Loophole (る)!" What? What loophole? What law says that the king gets to steal your stuff?
Imagine reading through a giant text called "The Law" and looking for this loophole the king's men claim to have about taking your lapis lazuli. You can't find it... but maybe if you search just a bit longer...
